subNodes.conversationText: The command came late -- most of the band had already retreated. The fighting had been fierce, but no one had died.
"Watch your step, witch. You've made enemies of us."
"Watch your step. People can be careless when they're running away."
"I don't run," she said, turning from the witch.
The magician glided into the woods, her feet a few inches above the forest floor.
The body that she had kicked lay where the brigands left it. It was that of a middle-aged man, plump and dressed well. He had been beaten and stabbed multiple times.
"They're new to killing but quite earnest about it," <FirstName> mused.
The corpse had probably been picked clean, but it was possible the bandits had missed something.

The bandits had been less thorough than <FirstName> expected -- or perhaps <he/she>'d come upon them before they'd had a chance to search their prey. The man had no money, but he wore a silver ring. It was a wayfarer's ring, signifying the blessing of some tutelary spirit.

It was hard to get off. The man's fingers were fat and clammy. The young witch had to grab his wrist with one hand and pull hard with <his/her> other, and even then the ring didn't budge. The look of agony on the corpse's face -- a vestige of the pain and terror of his death -- gave <FirstName> the perverse notion that <his/her> forceful attempt was hurting him.
At last the ring came off. <FirstName> pocketed it.

<He/She> had Knott roll the corpse into the woods. Meanwhile, the crow had become a little too curious. He had flitted around it while it was being moved. Now he was hopping up and down the body and poking at it with his beak.

<He/She> had Knott roll the corpse into the woods. Meanwhile, the crow had become a little too curious. He had flitted around it while it was being moved. Now he was hopping up and down the body and poking at it with his beak.

<He/She> had Knott roll the corpse into the woods. Meanwhile, the crow had become a little too curious. He had flitted around it while it was being moved. Now he was hopping up and down the body and poking at it with his beak.
<FirstName> waited until the crow was done investigating.
The corpse was too new and unyielding for Pharaoh's beak. He flew back to the witch's shoulder.

<He/She> had Knott roll the corpse into the woods. Meanwhile, the crow had become a little too curious. He had flitted around it while it was being moved. Now he was hopping up and down the body and poking at it with his beak.
The corpse had probably been picked clean, but it was possible the bandits had missed something.
The young witch gave no more thought to the crime.
The corpse had probably been picked clean, but it was possible the bandits had missed something.
"Forced? I didn't know witches could be forced to do anything," she said. Then she turned away.
